title: Eddie Jones provides update on Billy Vunipola injury after England win
text:
The 26-year-old had his ankle heavily strapped and was then withdrawn at half-time (Picture: Getty)

Billy Vunipola was removed at half-time with an apparent ankle injury to leave England fans worried about his status going forward in the Rugby World Cup.

Vunipola has been plagued by injury during his career, breaking his arm three times in 2018 alone and finally appears to be fully fit coming into the 2019 Rugby World Cup.

The No 8 has made 12 starts for England in 2019 having been named in Eddie Jones’ XV to face Argentina, something he has never done in his international career.

But he only lasted 40 minutes after receiving treatment and strapping on his left ankle during the first half, and was substituted at half-time as England won 39-10.

England coach Eddie Jones was typically enigmatic on the injury after the game.

”He slipped on some Kobe beef,’ Jones joked.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘He twisted his ankle, we don’t think it’s too serious.’

Lewis Ludlam came off the bench to replace him but the Northampton Saints player is a flanker as opposed to a No 8 and as former England head coach Sir Clive Woodward pointed out when speaking as an ITV pundit, Vunipola is the only player dedicated to that position.

‘He is pretty irreplaceable,’ Woodward said.

‘He’s not playing that well at the moment, he’s not 10 out of 10 but he is pretty irreplaceable because he is the only out-and-out No 8 in the squad.’

The Lions qualified for the knockout stages with a strong display (Picture: Getty)

England did look a different side without their star ball-carrier at the base of the scrum but Jones was quick to point out that they had not been in action for a while.

‘We’re exactly where we wanted to be with 15 points after three games,’ Jones added.

‘We just needed to simplify our game a little bit [at half-time]. With them having one off, we were probably trying to push the game a little bit too much.

‘We’re a bit rusty too after two easy games and a long break. That came out in the first half and second half we got a bit better rhythm.’
